rememberedPersonSummary.name: Julie Quantrill (Nee Hamilton)
story:
On the evening of the 14th October 2021, Julie Quantrill died peacefully with Pete at her side after a relatively short battle with Pancreatic Cancer.

Unfortunately, by the time Julie ended up in hospital and underwent a scan in late August it was discovered that it was too late for any effective treatment, and from 4th September she was in Roxburghe House in Aberdeen receiving palliative care. Our thanks, praise and admiration go to the team at Roxburghe House who have cared and watched over her for these last few weeks - we could not have wished for any better for her.

Due to the COVID restrictions, Julie's funeral will sadly have to be a small gathering which will be held at 11.00 on 25th October 2020 at Baldarroch Crematorium. However, it is our intention, at Julie's request, to hold an event when possible where her friends and wider family can congregate to remember and celebrate her life.

Our faith (and Julie's!) means that we believe that she is now in a better place with our Maker, but that will not stop Pete, Jamie, Ailsa, Penny, Andy and Annie missing her massively and wondering why we have been left when she has been taken. Please hold us in your prayers as we face the future without Julie in our earthly lives.

Julie asked that those who wanted to give something in her memory do so to support the work of Roxburghe House and Macmillan both of whom contributed to her care in the last weeks.

story:
I am Deborah Sandercock-Pickles and I have peritoneal cancer. During Lockdown I was shielding and in a moment of madness decided to jog or walk (depending on how my body felt) virtually around the garden. I would make certain stops on route and research the area. I am a vicar, so I thought that I would contact a local church at the places I have stopped at, visit their church website/facebook page, send them an E-mail and pray for them. I has been lovely receiving so many replies. I am currently in Scotland (virtually) on the final part of my journey. When I finish I will have travelled 1150 miles which is 17250 laps around the garden - which is looking like a mud bath at the moment!

I wanted to raise money for CRUK as 1 in 2 people will be affected by cancer in their lives. Research is the only way forward in finding a cure for different types of cancer. Unfortunately my cancer cannot be treated by surgery or radiotherapy, so I am dependent on ongoing chemotherapy. I am jogging in memory of all those who I have known who have died of cancer, particularly Don Young, Wendy, Joan, Simon and Doreen. I am also doing those have undergone treatment and overcome their cancer and those who are determined not to let the cancer beat them - including myself. Stay strong!

This is also in memory of my mum and brother, who are no longer with us.

This challenge is also also about saying thank you to all who have supported me on my battle against cancer over the past year and a half. You will never know how much your support has meant to me and will continue to be as I continue to fight this battle.

story:
Hello and thank you for looking at my fundraising page. I am completing the 75 Hard Challenge in memory of my beautiful friend Selina Carthy. The challenge includes eating a healthy diet, drinking a gallon of water a day, avoiding all alcohol and refined sugar and other junk food, reading at least 10 pages of non-fiction daily, and doing 2 separate stints of exercise each day, each one lasting at least 45 minutes and with at least one of the exercise challenges being outside. I need to do this every day for the next 75 days. If I have a blip, I will need to start again from Day 1. 

Why on Earth would I be doing such a crazy thing with the days getting colder and with the Christmas period approaching?   

It is hard to put into words the void that Selina leaves, so I will just leave a version of my tribute to her that was included in the service booklet for her funeral. Selina's husband Neil had requested that we do not send flowers but to send any donations to Cancer Research UK in her memory instead, and this is why I have chosen this cause. Thank you again for taking the time to look at this page and for considering this extremely worthy cause. 

Sumi Janmohamed Rampling

------

Selina was that sassy, spirited, outspoken girl at school who stood for Labour in our school mini-elections and purposefully irritated the sea of Conservatives that made up our student body. I was that quiet, uncertain girl hiding behind a book. Selina saw beyond what most others dismissed, and so I have been her honoured friend since the age of 11.

 Selina knew all the routes in and around London by both bus and by car, and she found my lack of direction-sense shocking. She had to advise me on which bus to take to get from my home in Ealing to her house in Perivale. The 297 from Castlebar Road and the 83 from Ealing Broaday are two bus routes that I will never forget, because Selina made sure of it. 

 Selina and I, along with a few other friends, would invariably spend New Year’s Eve together. In the early years, we would gate-crash Selina’s parents’ parties to hoard big plates of the chicken that her dad had so beautifully marinated, along with tubs of Häagen-Dazs for dessert. We would then set up in the conservatory to watch films back to back (Jean Claude Van Damme featured prominently, at Selina’s insistence). Fast forward a year or two, when we would take the train in to Central London to see what all the fuss was about, get the night bus home and THEN sit down in the conservatory to watch films (still featuring the Muscles from Brussels) and perhaps have a boogie to Bruce Springsteen.

When we were at our respective universities, I remember speaking to Selina via payphone and wondering, “How much of our adventures will we be able to recount to each other before this 50p runs out…?” I remember visiting her in Leeds where she was in her element, drinking cocktails at Henry’s Bar and frequenting that terrible 1990s night club which seemed almost identical to the equally terrible night club that I frequented in Cardiff where I was studying. 

 The phone calls continued when I moved to Australia, and there I heard about Selina’s new adventures and parties… and this guy called Neil who managed to steal her heart in a flash.

When I lived in the USA and Selina learnt that I was going through a stressful period, she sent me off to New York City where I got pampered with beautiful snacks, herbal teas and the best massage I've ever had. 

Then, when I eventually returned to the UK, Selina took it upon herself to be my personal matchmaker. I must say she was terrible at it, but nobody was happier than she when I finally settled down with the right person. She even offered to host my Mehndi ceremony in her beautiful home, not minding that this would involve hundreds of my friends and family members traipsing in and out of it. Not wanting to take advantage of her generosity I declined, although I suspect that she was actually a little disappointed that I did! 

Selina and Shoma also planned my hen-do with no holds barred. They put the management of the Ritz in a complete tizzy when we turned up in our sashes, heart balloons and tiaras (ok, the tiara was just me) — quite frankly, they had never seen anything quite like this within their hallowed walls. 

 Selina always remained a force in my life. She spurred me on when my confidence dipped and told me I was a mover and a shaker when I felt like I was at rock bottom. She celebrated good times with me, and pampered me when I was stressed or in need of some love by booking massages and facials. 

Selina is the most kind, giving, strong, spirited person that I have ever met. She did everything in her own unique way, she did it in style and she did nothing by halves. I am torn between absolute devastation that I must walk through the next stages of life without her and sheer gratitude that we walked through so many stages of our physical lives together. I will miss you, beautiful friend — have a peaceful ascent.

pageSummary: Raise awareness of the damage caused by palm oil. because they are protecting our natural world
pageSummaryWhat: Raise awareness of the damage caused by palm oil.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
During November I am challenging myself not to consume or use any palm oil products.

 Palm oil has been and continues to be a major driver of deforestation of some of the worlds most biodiverse forests 🌲, destroying the habitat of already endangered 🦧🐘🦏.

Palm oil plantations are seriously harming our environment by releasing massive amounts of CO2 in the air as the rain forests are cleared, like releasing a carbon bomb 💣.

Each day rain forests are destroyed to the equivalent of 300 soccer fields each HOUR! Why do we think this is okay!?

Through this I hope to raise money for WWF but more importantly raise awareness to what palm oil is and where it’s used ( in most things we consume and use daily) which means we are all directly guilty of destroying our natural world.

Please give what you can and share my awareness 🙏🏼 

Lx


WWF is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive.Your support is much appreciated.Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk
